title: 108_s3024
content: The "National Center for Transportation Solutions Act of 2004" establishes the National Center for Transportation Solutions and outlines its duties, organization, powers, and personnel matters. It also authorizes the creation of regional centers for transportation solutions and provides for the appointment of a Director of National Transportation Research. Congress finds that research and development are crucial for a transportation system that meets safety, mobility, economic vitality, efficiency, equity, and environmental protection goals. Federal investment in transportation research is only about 1% of overall government spending on transportation programs, despite a 40% increase in funding for transportation programs in the Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century. While Congress increased overall transportation funding by 40% in the Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century, funding for transportation research and development remained stagnant. Inadequate resources are allocated to long-term transportation research goals, and a competitive, peer-reviewed approach is needed to address strategic research needs amidst diverse transportation programs catering to different customers. The competitive, peer-reviewed award of research funding is best suited to address long-term, strategic transportation research needs, despite challenges posed by diverse research programs. The wide-ranging subject matter of transportation research makes effective priority setting difficult. To ensure the United States transportation system meets safety, mobility, economic vitality, equity, and environmental protection goals, increasing Federal investment in long-range planning and supporting competitive, peer-reviewed research into systemic transportation issues is crucial. The United States aims to increase Federal investment in long-range transportation planning, support competitive research into systemic transportation issues, better coordinate research programs, foster data interchange, and establish nationwide priorities in transportation research and development. The National Center for Transportation Solutions is established as an independent agency in the executive branch of government. It consists of the National Center for Transportation Solutions Board and the Director of National Transportation Research. The Board will exercise the authorities of the Center. The National Center for Transportation Solutions is tasked with developing a long-term national policy for research and development in multimodal transportation, supporting projects with public benefits or market failures. The National Center for Transportation Solutions awards grants to research institutions for long-term transportation objectives and facilitates data interchange among interested parties in the United States. The National Center for Transportation Solutions facilitates data interchange among interested parties in the United States by serving as a clearinghouse of information, consulting with transportation officials, and coordinating research programs with public and private groups. The National Center for Transportation Solutions coordinates transportation research programs with public and private groups, evaluates government research programs, and submits an annual report to Congress on its activities. The Director of National Transportation Research submits an annual report to Congress on the Center's activities, including recommendations for research and development in multimodal transportation. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board is established. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board is established with 16 voting members, including appointments by the Secretary of Transportation, the Director of the National Academies, and the President in consultation with the Senate majority leader. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board consists of 16 voting members appointed by the Secretary of Transportation, the Director of the National Academies, and the President in consultation with Senate leaders. Members must represent various professions and sectors. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board consists of 16 members appointed by the Secretary of Transportation, the Director of the National Academies, and the President with Senate consultation. Members must represent diverse professions, regions, and possess relevant skills. Initial appointments should be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board consists of 16 members appointed by various authorities. Initial appointments must be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment, with members serving staggered 6-year terms. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board members have staggered terms, with six members serving for six years, five for four years, and five for two years. Members can serve for more than two consecutive terms. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board members have staggered terms, with six members serving for six years, five for four years, and five for two years. Members can serve for more than two consecutive terms. Terms do not expire during election years. Initial terms can be extended for up to one year at the Director's discretion. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board members have staggered terms. Vacancies do not affect the Board's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Board must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board members have staggered terms. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Board must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. Meetings are called by the Chair, and a majority of members constitute a quorum. The Board selects a Chairman and Vice Chairman from its members. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board selects a Chairman and Vice Chairman from its members for 2-year terms, with a limit of two consecutive terms for the Chairman. SEC. 6. DIRECTOR OF NATIONAL TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH. The Director of National Transportation Research, appointed by the President with Senate consent, serves as the chief executive officer of the Center, carries out its authorities, and is a nonvoting member of the Board for a six-year term. The Director of the Center is appointed by the President, serves as the chief executive officer, and is a nonvoting member of the Board for a six-year term. The Director's salary cannot exceed the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 7. ORGANIZATION OF CENTER. The Center shall be organized into divisions including Transportation Safety, Environmental Planning, Infrastructure, Intermodal Connections, and Transportation Economics. Each division shall have a committee for recommendations and consultation. Each division under the Center shall have a committee composed of at least five members to advise on relevant issues. Committee members serve two-year terms and may elect a chairman annually. Each division committee consists of at least five members advising on relevant issues, serving two-year terms. The committee elects a Chairman annually and sets its own procedures within Board restrictions. The Center has powers outlined in Section 8. The Board and division committees have the authority to conduct hearings, gather information from Federal agencies, and receive necessary information to carry out the Act. The Board and division committees can request information from Federal agencies to carry out the Act. The Board is authorized to enter contracts and agreements, including sole source agreements with entities like the National Academy of Sciences. They can also use postal services for communication. The Board and division committees can accept gifts, publish research results, and use postal services like other Federal agencies. SEC. 9. CENTER PERSONNEL MATTERS. The Director of the Center may appoint and terminate staff without following civil service laws. The staff is responsible for submitting strategic and annual plans, as well as developing the Center's annual budget. The Director of the Center is responsible for submitting multiyear strategic plans, annual plans, and budgets, administering programs, providing staff support, and reporting progress to the Board. Coordination with other departments is also required. The Director of the Center is responsible for reporting progress to the Board and coordinating with other transportation organizations to leverage resources. The Director may set compensation for Center personnel independently of certain regulations. The Director of the Center has the authority to set compensation for personnel without following certain regulations. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Center without reimbursement. The Director of the Center has the authority to set compensation for personnel without following certain regulations. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Center without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status and privileges. The Director may also procure temporary and intermittent services at specified rates. The Director of the Center can set compensation for personnel under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. Volunteer services can be accepted without following certain regulations. SEC. 10. REGIONAL CENTERS FOR TRANSPORTATION SOLUTIONS. The Director shall award grants to establish regional centers for transportation solutions in four regions of the United States by September 30, 2005. These centers will conduct research on long-term regional multimodal transportation issues with clear public benefits. The transportation issues of long-term significance with clear public benefits and private investment not optional due to market failures or distortions. The Northeast Regional Center will be located in one of the 5 States with the highest levels of traffic congestion in the United States. The Northeast Regional Center will be located in a State that is among the top 5 States for traffic congestion based on specific criteria related to National Highway System roads. Authorization of appropriations from the Highway Trust Fund for fiscal years 2006 to 2010: $50,000,000 in 2006, $100,000,000 in 2007, $150,000,000 in 2008, $200,000,000 in 2009, and $250,000,000 in 2010.
